review.title: Most central or least central? How much modeling decisions influence a node's centrality ranking in multiplex networks
review.abstract: To understand a node's centrality in a multiplex network, its centrality values in all the layers of the network can be aggregated. This requires a normalization of the values, to allow their meaningful comparison and aggregation over networks with different sizes and orders. The concrete choices of such preprocessing steps like normalization and aggregation are almost never discussed in network analytic papers. In this paper, we show that even sticking to the most simple centrality index (the degree) but using different, classic choices of normalization and aggregation strategies, can turn a node from being among the most central to being among the least central. We present our results by using an aggregation operator which scales between different, classic aggregation strategies based on three multiplex networks. We also introduce a new visualization and characterization of a node's sensitivity to the choice of a normalization and aggregation strategy in multiplex networks. The observed high sensitivity of single nodes to the specific choice of aggregation and normalization strategies is of strong importance, especially for all kinds of intelligence-analytic software as it questions the interpretations of the findings.

sections.heading: II. DEFINITIONS, DATA SETS, NORMALIZATION AND AGGREGATION STRATEGIES
sections.text: We define a multiplex network as a network with | L | layers L = {L1, L2, · ·, L | L |}, where each layer li is a simple graph consisting of a node set Vi and an edge set Ei Vi · Vi, with ni: = | Vi | nodes and mi: = | Ei | edges. Each edge set Ei represents a certain type of interaction; the set of nodes common between the layers l1 to l | L | i is called V х = | L | i = 1 Vi. The degree degi (v) of any node v is defined as the number of edges connected to the node v in layer Li.

sections.heading: A. Datasets
sections.text: The first multiplex network data set is a subset of the European Airlines Network, which comprises 37 levels of airlines and was compiled by Cardillo et al. [12] The airports are represented as nodes and two nodes are connected when the corresponding airline offers a flight between the respective cities. As the 37 levels do not share common nodes, we use the following two subgroups of airlines: Air Berlin, Easyjet, Lufthansa and Ryan Air. The details of these four layers are listed in Table Ia; the four airlines share 9 airports. We also use another subset by removing Lufthansa; it leads to 20 shared airports between Air Berlin, Easyjet and Ryan Air.The second data set is a Twitter-related network of users interested in studying the Higgs Boson particle, compiled by De Domenico et al. [8] The different layers represent four directed networks of users who mention other users in their tweets.

sections.heading: B. Different Normalization Methods
sections.text: The result of normalization and aggregation is a ranking of all common nodes in V-2 and 2-layer subdivisions (from position 1 (among them) to position 2 (V-layer). Here we describe how the degree of all common nodes (V-layer) is normalized, from which then only the nodes in V-layer 1, for layer 1, for layer Li, for layer Li, for layer Li, for layer Li, for layer Li, for layer 2, for layer Li, for layer Li, for layer Li, for layer Li, for layer Li, for layer Li, for layer Li, for layer Li, for layer Li, for layer I, for layer II, for layer II, for layer V, and for layer V, for layer I, for layer I, for layer I, for layer II, and for layer II, and for layer I, for layer I, for I, for I, for I, for I, for I, and for I, for I, for I, for I, for I and for I, for I, for I, for I, for I, for I for I, and for I, for I for I, for I, and for I, for I for I, for I, for I for I, and for I, for I for I, for I, for I, for I for I, for I, for I for I, and for I, for I for I, for I, for I for I, and I for I for I, and for I for I, for I for I, for I, for I for I, and I for I, for I, for I for I, and I for I, and I for I for I, for I, and I for I, for I, for I, for I, and I for I, and I for I, and I for I for I, and I, for I, and I for I for I, and I, and I for I for I, and I, for the nodes of all common nodes, for the nodes, for the nodes, and V-nodes, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V, and V,

sections.heading: C. Different Aggregation Strategies
sections.text: In this paper, we consider the resulting normalized degree of nodes according to their highest normalized degree or their normalized layer WA. "For the aggregation of these multiple criteria, a single operator is increasingly used, representing the maximum weighting of different, possibly conflicting criteria [14]. He explained that the aggregation of multiple criteria in a decision-making problem can be scaled from a series of alternatives between two extreme cases of pure OR and pure AND. In pure OR, the maximum value among the criteria is the result of the aggregation, and in pure AND, the minimum value among the criteria is of interest. In the first case, this is a solution that meets at least one criterion, in the second case even the least satisfactory criteria must be high.

sections.heading: III. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text: Figure 2.a presents the resulting rankings of two airports in the air transport networks (all four carriers) (78 layers each). (β = β = 78 layers) A curve for each normalization method (β = 99 layers) is plotted against the selected β-value representing the aggregation strategy. Rankings are relative rankings of the 9 common nodes that exist in all four layers. However, keep in mind that a high β-value (high ORness = high ANDness) prefers nodes with a high minimum degree of centralization in at least one layer, a β-value of 0 (an ORness of 0.5) ranking points according to their average degree of centralization and a low β-value (high ORness = high ANDness) preferring nodes with the highest minimum degree of centralization. In relation to all four layers, Manchester Airport is an interesting case, as shown in Figure 2.a) Its actual grade in the four layers of the airlines is maximum (5, 5, 5, 5, 5, 5, 5, 5, 5, and 5, respectively).

sections.heading: IV. CONCLUSION
sections.text: The intuitive examination of the centrality of nodes in this paper shows that even seemingly simple and insignificant modeling decisions, such as normalization and aggregation strategies, result in very different ranking positions of nodes in multiplex networks. Furthermore, the visual method presented in this paper allows to categorize nodes based on their sensitivity to different aggregation or normalization strategies, for both or for none. Furthermore, the small dataset of an airline network is the first promising example that leads to very interesting insights. The large dataset of a tweet network shows even more interesting cases that exhibit a very high sensitivity to the choice of both aggregation and normalization strategies. Another interesting case can be found in the medium-sized dataset of a law firm: it shows a high sensitivity to the choice of aggregation strategy. The experimental results underscore the need to relate all kinds of preliminary processing steps to analyzing the diversity resulting from it.

referenceMentions.context: INTRODUCTION Classical Centrality indices have been numerously used and extended to quantify the importance of nodes in a network with respect to various network processes [1, 2, 3, 4].
INTRODUCTION Classical Centrality indices have been numerously used and extended to quantify the importance of nodes in a network with respect to various network processes [1, 2, 3, 4].
INTRODUCTION Classical Centrality indices have been numerously used and extended to quantify the importance of nodes in a network with respect to various network processes [1, 2, 3, 4].

It was soon noticed that a comparison of centrality index values of nodes in different networks requires a careful normalization: a degree of 100 might be considered more important than a degree of 200, if the first occurs in a network of order 150 and the second occurs in a network of order 500 [2].
The rapidly growing number of studies of multiplex networks in network science per se indicates that the analysis of complex systems needs more comprehensive network models and frameworks [5].
In such networks (also called multilayer networks), each layer itself is a network and the nodes are connected to each other with respect to different types of interaction or relationships [5].

While some authors allow edges between nodes from different layers [6, 7, 8, 9], here we restrict ourselves to multiplex networks comprised of multiple, non-interconnected layers with at least some nodes common to all layers.

While some authors allow edges between nodes from different layers [6, 7, 8, 9], here we restrict ourselves to multiplex networks comprised of multiple, non-interconnected layers with at least some nodes common to all layers.

While some authors allow edges between nodes from different layers [6, 7, 8, 9], here we restrict ourselves to multiplex networks comprised of multiple, non-interconnected layers with at least some nodes common to all layers.

While some authors allow edges between nodes from different layers [6, 7, 8, 9], here we restrict ourselves to multiplex networks comprised of multiple, non-interconnected layers with at least some nodes common to all layers.
Given a centrality index and a multiplex network, most authors suggest to use a vector of centrality index values, where each entry corresponds to the node’s value in one layer [10, 11].
Given a centrality index and a multiplex network, most authors suggest to use a vector of centrality index values, where each entry corresponds to the node’s value in one layer [10, 11].

Some authors have thus suggested to either use the sum or average of all centrality index values [11]; other strategies could be to rank by the maximum value achieved or by the minimum value obtained, to either stress the most successful ranking within one layer or the least successful and thus minimal centrality over all layers.

The different layers represent four directed networks of users mentioning other users in their tweets, users replying to the tweets of other users, users retweeting the tweets os other users, and the social network of based on the users following other users [8].

The third multiplex network represents different relationships between the employees of a Law firm dataset, compiled by Lazega (2001) [13] in a study of how 71 attorneys of a law firm communicate in terms of seeking advice, co-Working, and having a friendship outside the firm.
This results in a vector of normalized indices of [0, 1] for layer Li.

Different Aggregation Strategies In this paper, we consider the resulting normalized degree of |L| layers as |L| criteria and for the aggregation of these multiple criteria, we use Maximum Entropy Ordered Weighted Averaging (MEOWA) operator as described as follows: The MEOWA operator has been proposed by Yager for aggregating multiple numerical values, that represent the satisfaction of different, possibly opposing criteria [14].
The weight vector is obtained using the following function based on a parameter β [15]:
The produced weights are always between [0, 1] and the sum of the resulting weights is equal to 1.

Any βvalue between the extreme strategies of “at least one” and “all layers” can be interpreted as scaling and be described using a set of proportional linguistic quantifiers (a few, some, most, almost introduced by Zadeh [16] [17]) – we have discussed in our recent study [18] how the most influential node in a network can be identified using a fuzzy operator that includes these linguistic quantifiers.
